messages.text: Vaccinate certificate issued in 1908 during the reign of the Ottoman Sultan Abdülhamid II (d.1918).
Indian British soldier (part of the British Mandate police) searching Arab residents in Jerusalem, 1920.
Artistic depiction of Shaykh al-Akbar Muḥyiddin ibn Arabi (d.1240) — may God sanctify his noble secret.
The handwriting of Bahadur Shah Zafar (d.1862), the last Mughal emperor. Bahadur Shah was a man revered as a Sufi saint and he is one of the finest poets of the Urdu language.

"When someone asked Kirk Douglas (d.2020) which was his most memorable Thanksgiving Dinner. Kirk Douglas said Thanksgiving Dinner 1982 with the Afghan Mujahideen. He said while they were having dinner he told the Mujahideen that Thanksgiving was a special day in the USA. That is the day we Thank God for all he has given us. The Mujahideen said over here in Afghanistan we Thank God every day for what he has given us. Kirk Douglas said he continued eating his dinner quietly."
Mawlana Abul Kalam Azad  (d.1958) raising his hands in prayer at the resting place of his political rival Muhammad Ali Jinnah (d.1948) in Karachi, 1951.
A group of Algerian Muslims show their support for Algerian independence againts the French colonists in Algiers. December 1960.

The tomb of Sultan Mehmed II (d.1481) in the year 1890. He is popularly known as Mehmed the Conqueror. At the age of 21, he conquered Constantinople (modern-day Istanbul) and brought an end to the Byzantine Empire.
British Muslim Bangladeshi children, Whitechapel, London, 1986.

text: Palestinian women protesting the British Mandate in the 1940s.

messages.text:
Today marks the 90th anniversary of the martyrdom Omar al-Mukhtar (d.1931): The Lion of the Desert. Omar was an Islamic scholar and revolutionary who heroically led the resistance against the Italian occupation of Libya for almost 20 years. 

He was captured on September 11, 1931, after his horse was shot and fell to the ground in a clash near Ain el-Louf area. On September 15 of the same year, a mock trial was conducted for al-Mukhtar before being executed on September 16, 1931, in Suluq town, south of Benghazi.

May God have mercy on his soul.
The brave martyr: Omar al-Mukhtar (d.1931)

The tomb of Omar al-Mukhtar ر. This picture was taken in 1951.

شَيخ الشُّهَدَاء
Omar al-Mukhtar photographed with Libyan Senussi fighters.

Omar al-Mukhtar led the resistance against Italy's colonial drive to occupy modern-day Libya. The savage struggle saw Italy deploy chemical weapons, and concentration camps. Mukhtar was captured and sent to gallows by the Italians.

Omar al-Mukhtar's famous dying words in 1931 after the rope he was hung with broke: Italy is as weak as its ropes. His executioners were Italian Fascists who met an ignominious end, while Mukhtar's legacy lives on.

Omar is remembered as the Qur'an teacher who led by example and fought the occupiers to the death. Less known is that he was also a Sufi, and a humanist who abided by the Medina ethical code of war unlike his Fascist opponents.

Omar al-Mukhtar's status as a high symbol of resistance is a result of his absolute refusal to abandon his cause despite his old age and numerous attempts to bribe him. His view was: We don't belong in Italy, and Italy doesn't belong here.

Omar was executed because he refused to submit to Italian rule in exchange for his life. Today across the Arab and Muslim worlds streets, schools and public facilities carry his name. In his native Libya he is remembered as "Sidi Omar" or "Master Omar".
The Kab'ah during renovation in 1996.

The Hatim during renovation in 1996. The Hatim is the crescent shaped area immediately adjacent to the Ka’bah. Part of it is also known as the Hijr-Ismail as this was the place where Prophet Ibrahim constructed a shelter for his son Prophet Ismail and his wife Lady Hajrah.

Ahmad Domocao Alonto (d. 2002) was a Muslim-Filipino lawyer, educator, author, traditional leader, and Islamic scholar from Lanao del Sur.

He served as a Senator of the Philippines and was elected as a delegate in the 1971 Constitutional Convention and 1986 Philippine Constitutional Commission.

In 1954, he founded the Mindanao Islamic University (Jāmīatu al-Fīlībbīn al-Islāmi), the first Islamic university in the Philippine archipelago.

Alonto also amended the Civil Service Law of 1959, recognizing the Islamic holidays Id al-Fitr and Id al-Adha.

In 1988, he was awarded with the prestigious King Faisal Prize for his service to Islam.

Dr. Ahmad Domocao Alonto (d.2002) receiving the King Faisal Prize in 1988 for his service to Islam.

Dr. Alonto was a prominent Islamic figure in the Philippines and is considered one of the world’s greatest Islamic leaders of the 20th Century. He led the Islamic movement in his country for over 30 years and strove to unite Filipino Muslims, improve their living conditions, and secure their rights. At the same time, he was a preacher of non-violence and of peaceful co-existence between Filipino Muslims and Christians. In the 1950s, he was the only Muslim elected to the Filipino House of Representatives and subsequently the Senate.
Ottoman Caliph Abdulmejid II (d.1944) leaving the blue Mosque on his horse after the Friday prayers.

The keys to the Rawdah al-Sharifah (the Sacred Chambers) of the Messenger of Allah ﷺ.

A Bedouin of the desert visited the Prophet’s tomb and greeted the Prophet, addressing him directly as if he were alive. “Peace upon you, Messenger of God!” Then he said, “I heard the word of God ‘If, when they had wronged themselves . . .,’ I came to you seeking pardon for my mistakes, longing for your intercession with our Lord!” The Bedouin then recited a poem in praise of the Prophet and departed. The person who witnessed the story says that he fell asleep, and in a dream he saw the Prophet saying to him, “O ‘Utbi, rejoin our brother the Bedouin and announce [to] him the good news that God has pardoned him!”

Hafiz Mohammed Abdul Karim (d.1909) — The Munshi (language teacher) was an Indian attendant of Queen Victoria (d.1901). He served her during the final fourteen years of her reign, gaining her maternal affection over that time. She would take him on her travels and he taught her Urdu. Abdul Karim was one of two Indians who arrived in Britain to attend the Queen at the Royal Household. 

He was met with hostility by her attendants and immediate family.

Following Victoria's death in 1901, her successor, Edward VII (d.1910), returned Karim to India and ordered the confiscation and destruction of the Munshi's correspondence with Victoria.
Abdul Karim (d.1909) with his nephew Mohammed Abdul Rashid pictured together in England in the year 1897.

From left Abdul Karim, Princess Marie and Victoria Melita of Edinburgh, Duke of Connaught, Queen Victoria, Beatrice, Princess Henry of Battenberg (and back roow), S. Maslin, Princess Alix of Hesse, Princess Alexandra of Edinburgh, Princess Irene of Hesse, Mohammed Bukhsh all enjoying breakfast at Osborne House in August 1887.
The Urdu handwriting of Queen Victoria (d.1901). She was taught Urdu by her Indian attendant, Munshi Abdul Karim (d.1909).
The Urdu handwriting of Queen Victoria (d.1901). She was taught Urdu by her Indian attendant, Munshi Abdul Karim (d.1909).

text: A wedding ceremony in Qudüs, Palestine.

messages.text: Water being served in the Prophet's ﷺ Mosque, al-Masjid al-Nabawi, c.1960s.
Water buckets used to clean inside of the holy Kab'ah.

text: Bahraini soldiers during the Arab-Israeli war in 1948 carring a banner which reads: In the name of Allah, the Most Merciful, the Most Compassionate. We Bahrains sacrifice ourselves for Palestine, Arabs and indeed all Muslims.

messages.text: Indian and Turkish medics who served in the Balkan war (1912-3) supporting the Ottoman empire.

Shaykh Ibrahim Niasse (d.1975) and his daughter Shaykha Maryam Niasse in her youth. Shaykha Maryam is known in Senegal for her famous Qur'an School in the Capital city Dakar, which opened in the 1950’s and has seen tens of thousands of students from all over West Africa and the Arab world, studying and memorising the Qur'an and other Islamic sciences
King Saud bin 'Abd al-Aziz al-Saud (d.1969) can be seen wearing the ihram exiting the Kab'ah. He was the ruler of Saudi Arabia between 1953 and 1964.
The Huaisheng Mosque, China , c.1860s. The mosque was built 1300 years ago. The original minaret can be seen.

The handwriting of Imam Ahmed Rida Khan (d.1921), the famous Hanafi jurist, Islamic scholar, theologian and astectic based in India. Recognised by his followers as a Mujaddid (lit., reviver). Ahmed Rida Khan wrote on law, philosophy, religion (incd. Hadith, Tafsir and Fiqh). He wrote several hundred books in the Arabic, Persian and Urdu language.
Two Polish imams of Tatar heritage in Warsaw, Poland 1930s. On the left is Ali Smajkiewicz (d.1976) and on the right is Ali Ismail Woronowicz (d.1941).

One of the oldest photos which exist of Jabal an-Nur (he illuminated mountain), which is mountain near Makkah in the Hijaz region of Saudi Arabia. The mountain houses the cave of Hira or the Ghar-i Hira, which holds tremendous significance for Muslims throughout the world, as Prophet Muhammad ﷺ spent much time in this cave meditating, and was here that he ﷺ received the first Qur'an revelation.

A close up picture from 1956 showing the changing of the Kiswah (black cloth covering the Kab'ah). It is draped annually on the 9th day of the month of Dhu al-Hijjah, the day pilgrims leave for the plains of Mount Arafat during the Hajj.
Passports being checked by immigration officers at Madina Airport on the runway.
A music class in Kuwait City, Kuwait, 1967.
Funeral procession of a martyed Ottoman soldier - buried in the garden of the Old Beersheba Mosque, Palestine, 1917.
Mawlana Shah 'Abd al-Alim Siddiqi (d.1954) pictured on his arrival at Piarco Airport in Trinidad.

Friday prayers performed at the Jama Masjid Delhi, 1904. It is one of the largest Msoques in India. The Mosque was commissioned by the Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan (d.1666). The Baadshahi Mosque (Lahore, Pakistan) has a similar architectural design to the Jama Mosque as it was commissioned by Aurangzeb (d.1707) the son and successor of Shah Jahan.

The Saudi National day is celebrated in Saudi Arabia on every 23 September to commemorate the renaming of the Kingdom of Nejd and Hejaz to the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia by a royal decree from King Abdul Aziz Ibn Saud (d.1953) in 1932.

Image: Ibn Saud in Kuwait, 1910.

text: Muhammad Ali (d.2016) at a march for Palestine in 1988, Chicago.

messages.text: Muhammad Ali (d.2016) pictured at the Jama Masjid, Delhi, India - 1980s.
Muhammad Ali (d.2016) pictured at the Jama Masjid, Delhi, India - 1980s.

Sayeeda Khanam (d.2020) was the first female professional photographer of Bangladesh. She covered many important events of Liberation War of Bangladesh in 1971 through her photography.

In 1956, she began her career as a photographer in Begum, the only newspaper dedicated to women at that time. Her photographs have been published in several national newspapers and she covered many national and international seminars. Khanam also did portraits of figures such as Queen Elizabeth, Neil Armstrong, Buzz Aldrin, Mother Teresa, Indira Gandhi and Sheikh Mujibur Rahman.

Sir Ikbal Ali Shah (d.1969) was an Indian-Afghan author and diplomat descended from the sadaat (descendants of prophet Muhammad  ﷺ) of Pagham. Educated in India, he came to Britain as a young man to continue his education in Edinburgh, where he married a young Scotswoman.

Ikbal Shah was a prolific author who wrote on many subjects including Sufism. In his book "Islamic Sufism", Ikbal Shah stated that be was instructed in the Sufi way by his father, Nawab Sayyid Amjad Ali Shah Nakshbandi Paghmani who in turn was taught by his father, Nawab Sayyid Muhammad Ali Shah, who is buried in Delhi, at the shrine of the Nakshbandi Sufi scholar, Khawaja Baqi Billah (d.1603) — Khawaja Baqi Billah was a saint from Kabul, Afghanistan
DM on FB or Instagram.

text: Colourised footage of Ottoman Jerusalem, 1897.

messages.text: Asli Hassan Abade (born in 1958) was the first African women Air Force pilot in whole of Africa and midle east. She is a Somali Air force pilot, military figure, and civil activist. She was the first and so far the only female pilot in the Somali Air Force.

Enver Paşa (d.1922) pictured with his mother. Enver was a Ottoman general and commander in chief, and a prominent member of the Young Turk Revolution of 1908 (a revolutionary movement against the authoritarian regime of Ottoman sultan Abdülhamid II d.1918). He was a convicted war criminal.

He played a key role in the Ottoman entry into World War I on the side of Germany, and, after the Ottoman defeat in 1918, he attempted to organize the Turkic peoples of Central Asia against the Soviets.

The Istanbul trials of 1919–1920 were courts-martial of the Ottoman Empire that occurred soon after the Armistice of Mudros, in the aftermath of World War I.

CUP's leaders, Enver, Djemal, Talaat, among others, were ultimately sentenced to death under charges of wartime profiteering, and massacres of both Armenians and Greeks.

Rokeya Sakhawat Hossain (d.1932), commonly known as Begum Rokeya, was a Bengali feminist thinker, writer, educator and political activist from British India. She is widely regarded as a pioneer of women's liberation in South Asia.

Her writings - which spanned poetry, fiction and essays - espoused radical ideas for gender equality and envisioned a better and fairer world for women.
An interesting painting from an Italian magazine from August 1947 depicting the historical moment of independence of India and Pakistan from the Colonial British rule.
A 1981 advertisement in Soldier of Fortune Magazine.
The swastika on a Nazi Germany airplane purchased by the Turkish Air Force is replaced with the star and crescent, 1937.

Zainab Cobbold (d.1963), born Lady Everyln Murray, was a Scottish noblewoman who was known for her conversion to Islam in the victorian era. After the death of her husband in 1929 she started to plan her Hajj pilgrimage, she contacted Hafiz Wahba (d.1967), ambassador for Kingdom of Hejaz and Najd to the United Kingdom, who in turn sent a letter to King Abd al-Aziz (d.1953).

Evelyn achieved celebrity status in 1933 at the age of 65, when she became the first Muslim woman born in the United Kingdom to perform the Hajj pilgrimage to Makkah.

In 1934, a personal account of her trip was published entitled Pilgrimage to Mecca.

She passed away at the age of 96, and was buried, according to her wishes, on a rural hill in Scotland, facing Makkah, with the words of the Qur'an engraved on her gravestone.

Image: The Author in Pilgrim Dress.

Ibrahim Fejić (d. 1962) was a Bosnian Islamic theologian who served as the mayor of Mostar from 1929 until 1934 and as the Grand Mufti of the Yugoslav Islamic Community from 1947 until 1957. He is most remembered for his endorsement of the campaign against the veiling of Muslim women.

Dietary requirements of Muslims and Sikh soldiers during the World War One. Indian soldiers sitting with animals in front of a butcher shop. The left side reads: Mohammedan Meat House. The right side reads: Hindoo Meat House.

The notice board on the right hand side should actually read: Sikh Meat House, as traditional Hindus do not consume meat as part of their religious requirements. 
.

The All India Jamhur Muslim League (Urdu: آل انڈیا جمہور مسلم لیگ‎) was formed in 1940, to counter the Lahore resolution, passed by the All-India Muslim League, for a separate Muslim stated based on the Two Nation Theory.

Mahatma Gandhi (d.1948) and Ghaffar Khan (d.1988)  with a member of the Khaksar Tehrik (movement). The Khaksar movement (Urdu: تحریکِ خاکسار‎) was a social movement based in Lahore, Punjab, British India, established by Allama Mashriqi (d.1963) in 1931, with the aim of freeing India from the rule of the British Empire and establish a Hindu-Muslim government in India.

Kazi Nazrul Islam (d.1976) was a Bengali poet, writer, philosopher, and the national poet of Bangladesh. Popularly known as Nazrul, he produced a large body of poetry and music with themes that included religious devotion and rebellion against oppression. 

Born in a Bengali Muslim Kazi family, Nazrul Islam received religious education and as a young man worked as a muezzin at a local mosque. 

He joined the British Indian Army in 1917 and was posted in Karachi. Nazrul established himself as a journalist in Calcutta after the war ended. He criticised the British Raj and called for revolution through his poetical works.

His nationalist activism in Indian independence movement led to his frequent imprisonment by the colonial British authorities.

He was multi talented and also wrote in the Arabic, Persian and Urdu language.
A group of Mevlevi Dervishes. 1870.
Two prominent African American Muslims.

Sir Sayyid Ahmed Khan (d.1898) was a teacher and politician. He was a philospher as well. He was also a social reformer. He founded the school that would later become Aligarh Muslim University.

His works, in Urdu, include Essays on the Life of Mohammed (1870) and commentaries on the Bible and on the Qur'an. In 1888 he was made a Knight Commander of the Star of India.

Sayyid’s family was highly regarded by the Mughal dynasty. His father, who received an allowance from the Mughal administration; his maternal grandfather had twice served as prime minister of the Mughal emperor of his time and had also held positions of trust under the East India Company. Sayyid’s brother established one of the first printing presses at Delhi and started one of the earliest newspapers in Urdu, the principal language of the Muslims of northern India.

India’s first mosque, the Cheraman Jama Masjid in Kodungallur, Kerala, has remained a source of fascination as well as an active place of worship for well over a thousand years. Built during Prophet Muhammad’s ﷺ lifetime, this landmark building is among the most important of India’s historic, architecturally stunning mosques.

Malik Bin Dinar, one of the first propagators of Islam to have come to the Indian subcontinent, built the Cheraman Jama Masjid. Among the many stories in circulation about the mosque’s origins, the most popular recounts how Cheraman Perumal, the region’s king, gave up his throne to embrace Islam and make a pilgrimage to Makkah. After years spent in Makka, the king decided to return home but fell ill and died on the way. However, Malik Bin Dinar and his companions completed the king’s journey on his behalf. They carried with them a series of letters written by Cheraman Perumal asking local rulers of Kerala for their permission to build the area’s first mosques.
The handwriting of Allama Iqbal (d.1938).
Srilankan Jewelers. A Muslim business can be seen inspecting a piece of jewellery on the left hand side, c.1960s.
Illuminated night view of the Kab'ah, c.1950s. The mataf area was first lt with electric light bulbs in the 1920s. In the year 1949 the sacred Mosque was illuminated by its own generators.

The al-Baqi cemetery is the oldest and first Islamic cemetery of Madina of the Hejazi region of modern-day Saudi Arabia. 

The ground holds much significance for the Muslim community as it housed the resting place of many of Prophet Muhammad's ﷺ family and Companions.

This picture is from the 1970s.

text:
The earliest credible evidence of either coffee drinking or knowledge of the coffee tree appears in the middle of the 15th century, in Yemen's Sufi monasteries. The Sufis used it to keep themselves alert during their night time devotions.

Image: Banī Ṣakhr Bedouins making coffee, 1906.

messages.text: Bektashi Sufi Dervishes, Albania.
King Faisal (d.1975) can be seen exiting Kab'ah after the ritiual cleaning, late 1960s or early 1970s.
The Saudi flag being hoisted, 1936.
Smile!

Miya Muhammad Bakhsh (d.1907) was an outstanding Sufi poet hailing from Mirpur, Kashmir. He is especially renowned as the author of a book of poetry called Sayf al-Muluk, his magnum opus, which is a story of a Prince with strong Sufi undertones. He also also Masnavi nayrang-i Ishq (re-working of Mevlana Rumi's Masnavi). 

Miya Muhammad Bakhsh received his early education at home and was later sent with his elder brother, Mīān Bahāval, to the nearby village of Samwal Sharīf to study religious sciences, especially the science of Hadith in the madrassah of Hāfiz Muhammad 'Alī. 

His poetry is essentially written in a mixed language composed of standard Punjabi and the Pothohari and Hinko dialects of Punjabi, and utilizes a rich vocabulary of Persian and Arabic words. Miya Muhammad Bakhsh, in his lifetime, contributed his great mystic thought in the language of the masses – Punjabi language which was also his mother tongue. He remained a celibate and passed away peacefully at an advanced age.

Nasir ad-din al-Albani (d.1999) was a proponent of Salafism and considered to be its primary figure heads in the 20th century. He is of Albanian-Syrian heritage, by trade he was a watch maker and is recognised as a Hadith specialist by his followers. Al-albani is often the recipient of heavy criticism for his unorthodox understanding (and approach) to the religion. His brother, father and grandfather were all traditional Sunni followers-of-tasawwuf scholars.

Dr Zakir Husain Khan (d.1969) assumed the office of the President of India in 1967. He was the first Muslim to become the President of India. The picture shows him being sworn in as vice-president in 1962.

Peter Sanders is a phenomenon British photographer who has spent over 50 years taking pictures of the Muslim community around the world, especially on their traditional and spiritual aspects. 

His most recent publication, Meetings with Mountains (2019) is an outstanding book which details his encounters with saints and sages of the Islamic world.

The sanctuary of Imam Ahmed Rida Khan (d.1921), the famous Hanafi jurist, Islamic scholar, theologian and astectic based in India. Recognised by his followers as a Mujaddid (lit., reviver). Ahmed Rida Khan wrote on law, philosophy, religion (incd. Hadith, Tafsir and Fiqh). He wrote several hundred books in the Arabic, Persian and Urdu language. Usha Sanya, in her book, Ahmed Riza Khan Barelwi writes: The subject of this book is of an Indian Muslim scholar...Ahmed Riza Barelwi (1856-1921). His writings and his interpretation of Islam laid the foundation for a movement known by its followers as the 'Ahl-e Sunnat wa Jama'at (devotees of the Prophet's practice and broad community).

Shaykh Ibrahim Niasse (d.1975) was a major Islamic scholar from West Africa. He was an established scholar who write many books on Islam (Fiqh, Hadith, Tafsir) and had a particular interest in tasawwuf. He is Shaykh al-Islam, an honorific title associated with outstanding scholars of the Islamic sciences.
King Faisal I (d.1933) of Iraq with his pet leopard, 1925.
Indian regiment buring dead Pakistani soldiers as per the Islamic tradition after the Pakistani government refused to acknowledge them in the aftermath of the Kargil War in 1999.

Imam and children from the Vallahades community (Greek-speaking Muslim population) raise their hands in prayers outside the village of Pigaditsa, 1923. The photo was taken by an English anthropologist and traveller, Margaret Hasluck on the eve of the Greece-Turkey population exchange.

Data Ali Hujwiri (d.1077), was the noble descendant of the celestial Prophet ﷺ. He lived in the 11th century and was revered as a Muslim saint and Islamic scholar who became famous for composing the Kashf al-Mahjub, recognised as one of the earliest treatises on Sufism in the Persian language.

This photograph is of the sanctuary of Data Ali Hujwiri taken 1928 by Dr L.E. Browne.
Greek Muslim men from the Vallaades community pictired in the local market, c.1910s.

text: Early 1900 picture of the Sanctuary of Medina the Radiant. Photographer: H. A. Mirza and Sons (Delhi Based photographers).
Early 1900 picture of the Sanctuary of Makkah the Great. Photographer: H. A. Mirza and Sons (Delhi Based photographers).

messages.text: The last King of Afghanistan Mohammed Zahir Shah (d.2007) pictured with Ayub Khan (d.1974), the second President of Pakistan.
The celestial abode.
Street vendors outside the Valide Sultan Mosque, 19th century.

Letter of gratitude sent by the directors of monasteries in Bosnia to Sultan Abdulmejid I (d.1861) for providing religious freedom, 5 July 1853

Bosna’da bulunan manastır müdürlerinin kendilerine verilen dini serbestlikten dolayı Sultan Abdülmecid’e gönderdikleri teşekkür mektubu, 5 Temmuz 1853

رسالة شكر من قبل رؤوساء الاديرة في البوسنة للسلطان عبدالمجيد لتأمينه الحرية الدينية، 5 
تموز من العام 1853
The tomb of Prophet Yahya ع (John the Baptist) located in the Ummayad Mosque, Syria, 1920.

text:
Heartfelt and profound greetings to your sublime soul. O incomparable Prophet and uniquely beloved one of Allah. 

May the Muhammadan light illuminate our hearts and souls. A very happy Mawlid al-Nabi to you and yours.
celebrated in Somalia in the year 1931.

celebrated in Somalia in the year 1950 with Sharif Muhammad ibn Sharif Aydarus (d.1960). Sharif Aydarus was a famous scholar of Islamic and Somali history and pan-Islamic leader. Sharif Muhammad is reciting the Mawlid (chornogical life story of Prophet Muhammad ﷺ) in front of a large crowd.

text:
in Makkah.

DM us to submit your
videos.

celebrated in London, 1939.

Abdullah Yusuf Ali (d.1953), the famous translator of the Qur'an into the English language, made a speech on this occasion under the title: The Prophet's Services to the Cause of Human Morality. Ambassadors from Muslim countries were in attendance.
The Garebeg festival celebrating

in Yogyakarta, Java Island, Indonesia, c.1920s. Garebeg, also grebeg, is the Javanese term for a grand ceremony celebrated three times a year at the kratons (royal courts) of Yogyakarta, Surakarta, and Cirebon, coinciding with the three Islamic feasts of
al-Nabi (birthday of the Prophet ﷺ), Id al-fitr (festival of the breaking of the fast) and Id al-adha (sacrificial feast).
Sufi Abdullah Khan Nakshbandi (d.2015) leading a
procession in the 1980s, Birmingham, UK. Abdullah Khan is pictured wearing a green thobe.
The circle points to the birthplace of the venerable Prophet ﷺ, Makkah, 1887.

messages.text: Sultan Abdul Hamid II (d.1918) sitting on his throne.

text: procession led by Ottoman Sultan Mehmed V (d.1918) in Istanbul, 1915.

messages.text: Ottoman Sultan Mehmed V (d.1918) hosting Kaiser Wilhelm II (d.1941, last German Emeror) in Constantinople on 15 October 1917.
Sultan Mehmed V (d.1918) greeting Kaiser Wilhelm II (d.1941) on his arrival at Constantinople.
King Faisal (d.1975) of Saudi Arabia pictured with the Grand Mufti of Palestine, Amin al-Husayni (d.1974).

text: celebration in Libya, 1930s

messages.text: Yearly dhikr gathering in Ajvatovica, near the village of Prusac (Bosnia and Herzegovina), 1910.

Shaykh al-Islam Khawaja Qamar ad-din Sialvi (d.1981). Qamar ad-din was an Islamic Scholar and a follower of the Chishti tradition. He was familiar with the Qur’an by the age of nine and received his religious education at several institutions, including ones in Makkah and Ajmer.

He is also credited for being one of the foremost and staunchest supporters of the movement for the creation of Pakistan.

Jabir Herbert Muhammad (d.2008) was Muhammad Ali's (d.2016) longtime boxing Manager. He was also a successful businessman and co-founded Top Rank, Inc (Boxing promotional company). Muhammad was born in Detroit, Michigan, as the third son of the Nation of Islam leader, Elijah Muhammad (d.1975). Jabir Muhammad was a staunch supporter of his brother, Imam Warith Deen Muhammad (d.2008) whom he followed into Sunni Islam.
Muhammad Ali (d.2016) with the members of the Yemeni Shadhili Sufi community at the al-Azhar mosque in England with his newly wedded wife, Veronica Porsche in 1977.
Artistic depiction of the sanctuary of Imam Ali b. Abu Talib,  Najaf sharif. Bombay 20 century.

The al-Rashid Mosque was the first Mosque built in Canada in the year 1938. Hilwie Jomha Hamdon (d.1988) was a Muslim woman who organised funding for the Mosque. She, along with friends, collected fund from Jews, Christians and Muslims to construct the mosque.

The mosque was built by Ukrainian-Canadian contractor Mike Drewoth in a style resembling the Eastern Christian (Ukrainian Catholic and Orthodox) immigrant churches and opened on December 12, 1938. In the 1940s, the building was relocated from its original site to a location a few blocks away to make room for a school expansion.

Hilwie Taha Jomha Hamdon (d.1988) was a Canadian Muslim born in Lebanon in the year 1905. She was instrumental in rasing funds for the al-Rashid Mosque in the late 1930s (see previous post). She was a leader in her community and inspired other Muslim women to take on leadership roles.

text:
celebrated in Yemen, following in the footsteps of Abysinians who are reported to have held a similar performance in front of the Prophet Muhammad ﷺ in the 7th century. Enjoy!

DM us if you would like your
video featured.

text.text:
Anas ibn Mâlik (radiyallâhu anhu) said that the Abyssinians (Habashîs) danced in front of the Messenger of Allâh (sallallâhu alayhi wa sallam); dancing (yarquSûn/raqS) while saying "Muhammadis a Righteous Servant (Muhammadun Abdun Sâlih)" (in their dialect/language). Allâh's Messenger (sallallâhu alayhi wa sallam) asked, "What are they saying?" And they responded, "Muhammadun 'Abdun Sâlih!".

 [Ahmad ibn Hanbal, al-Musnad (Beirut: Dâr Sâdir), 3:152, #12564]

text: A map of Madina al-Munawwarah (the illuminated city) or Madinat an-Nabi (the city of the Prophet) and its vicinity. At the city's heart is al-Masjid an-Nabawi (he Prophet's Mosque), which is the burial place of the Islamic Prophet, Muhammad ﷺ. Madina is one of the three holiest cities in Islam, the other two being Makkah and Jerusalem.

messages.text: An Arab shop in Java, Indonesia, 1920s.
Yusuf Ziya Pasha (d.1929) was the Ottoman ambassador to the US.

text: Mawlana Shah 'Abd al-'Alim Siddiqi (d.1954) in South Africa leading a procession commerating the
of Prophet Muhammad ﷺ with other Islamic clerics.
The first President of The Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina Alija Izetbegovic (d.2003) at a
gathering with the dervishes of the Nakshbandi tekke (Sufi lodge) in Zivcici in the early 1990s.

messages.text: Muhammad Nadir Shah (d.1933) was the King of Afghanistan from 15 October 1929 until his assassination in November 1933.

Hassan al-Banna (d.1949) was an Egyptian political and religious leader who established a new religious society, the Muslim Brotherhood, and played a central role in Egyptian political and social affairs.

Thr Muslim Brotherhood (al-Ikhwān al-Muslimūn) was a religiopolitical organization founded in 1928. It advocated a return to the Qur’an  and the Hadith as guidelines for a healthy modern Islamic society. The Brotherhood spread rapidly throughout Egypt, Sudan, Syria, Palestine, Lebanon, and North Africa. Although figures of Brotherhood membership are variable, it is estimated that at its height in the late 1940s it may have had some 500,000 members.

The Association of Algerian Muslim Ulama (Jamʿiyyat al-ʿUlamāʾ al-Muslimīn al-Jazāʾiriyyīn) was a body of Muslim religious scholars who, under French rule, advocated the restoration of an Algerian nation rooted in Islamic and Arabic traditions. This picture was taken in 1931.
Sultan Abdülhamid II (d.1918) possibly pictured with Mustafa Kemal Ataturk (d.1938) in the background.

Rahmah el-Yunusiyah (d.1969) was a Minangnese woman and a pioneer of Islamic women education in Indonesia. She founded the first Islamic school in West Sumatra and later became a parliament member representing Central Sumatra Province in 1955.
Javanese women with hijab, 1923. The Javanese people are a Southeast Asian ethnic group native to the Indonesian island of Java.

of Prophet Muhammad ﷺ in the presence of the Sultan and other supreme officials, at the Sultan Ahmed Mosque, Istanbul, c.1780s.
celebration in Hijaz (modern day Saudi)  during the early 1900s.

messages.text: Eid prayers in Albania.

Hazrat Khawaja Pir Habib Ali Shah Chishti (d.1903) was major Sufi scholar from India. He was known much for his piety. He comes from a long lineage of sufi scholars is the direct progeny of the first saintly caliph, Amir al-Mu'minin Hazrat Abu Bakr as-Siddiq.

text: A diagramaric impression of the Prophet Muhammad's ﷺ sandal, Morocco, 17th/18th Century.
The night of Mawlid (the birth of Nabi ﷺ) is more superior than the Night of Power.

Inside the southern side of the Prophet's mosque.

The night of

(the birth of the sublime Prophet ﷺ) is more sacred than the Night of Power.  Heartfelt and profound greetings to your sublime soul. O incomparable Prophet and uniquely beloved one of Allah. 

The mother of the beloved Prophet Muhammad ﷺ said: The moment he [Muhammad] came from me, a light emerged that illuminated everything from East to West.

messages.text: A Bedouin of the desert visited the Prophet’s tomb and greeted the Prophet, addressing him directly as if he were alive. “Peace upon you, Messenger of God!” Then he said, “I heard the word of God ‘If, when they had wronged themselves . . .,’ I came to you seeking pardon for my mistakes, longing for your intercession with our Lord!” The Bedouin then recited a poem in praise of the Prophet and departed. The person who witnessed the story says that he fell asleep, and in a dream he saw the Prophet saying to him, “O ‘Utbi, rejoin our brother the Bedouin and announce [to] him the good news that God has pardoned him!”

messages.text: Malik el-Shabazz (d.1965, Malcolm X) receiving his certificate (ijazah) of recognition and authority after completing his studies for Da'wah (proselytisation) from the rector of al-Azhar, Hasan Maa'moun (d.1973) — The Grand Imam of al-Azhar or Shaykh al-Azhar between 1964 and 1969 and before that the Grand Mufti of Egypt between 1955 and 1960.

messages.text: The Mantle Odes Arabic Praise Poems by Suzanne Pinckney Stetkevych.

New logo! And we've also got some pre-recorded interview of Dr Karen Leonard who gave her insight on Hyderabad (India) and Muslims. Karen Leonard is a wonderful historian who reviews work on the history and culture of India, especially the former Hyderabad State, and on Asian American and Muslim American history and culture. Stay tuned!

East London, Brick Lane Mosque, 1970s? The building at 59 Brick Lane has been home to a succession of Christian, Jewish, and Muslim communities since its construction in the mid-eighteenth century, reflecting the waves of immigration in the neighbourhood of Spitalfields. 

The majority of worshippers of the mosque are of Bangladeshi descent; the mosque serves the largest concentration of Bangladeshi Muslims in the country.

messages.text: The Babri Masjid prior to its destruction. It was demolished in 1992 by the Hindutva extremists based on unfounded claims.

On this day in the year 1862, during the early hours of Friday, the last Mughal Emperor, Sultan Bahadur Shah, died at age of 87 during a forceful exile in Rangoon, modern-day Burma.

Bahadur Shah Zafar was a devout Sufi. He was regarded as a Sufi scholar. He was described as one of the leading saints of the age, approved of by the divine court. Before his accession, he lived like a dervish, differing from his three royal brothers, Mirza Jahangir, Salim and Babur.In 1828, a decade before he succeeded the throne, Major Archer said that: Zafar is a man of spare figure and stature, plainly apparelled, almost approaching to meanness, his appearance is that of an indigent munshi or teacher of languages.

text: The Basmala most likely written by Zainab Cobbold (d.1963), born Lady Everyln Murray — the first Scottish lady to perform the
pilgrimage after her conversion to Islam. The image is found in her book called Pilgrimage to Mecca published in 1934.

messages.text:
Abadi Bano Begum (d.1924) was one of the first Muslim women to actively take part in politics and became a prominent voice in the Indian independence movement against the notorious British Raj.

Born into a nationalist family in Uttar Pradesh in 1852, Abadi Bano Begum was married to Abdul Ali Khan, a senior official in Rampur at a young age. They had a daughter and five sons, including Mawlana Shaukat Ali and Mawlana Muhammad Ali Jauhar, who came to be known as the popular freedom fighters — the Ali brothers.

Indian Muslim troops serving with the British army, during Wolrd War One, pray outside the Shah Jahan Mosque in Woking, Surrey.

It is estimated that 1.5 million Indian troops fought to defend Britain. Of those, 400,000 were Muslim soldiers.

Subedar Khudadad Khan (d.1971) was the first Indian Muslim part of the British Indian Army to become the recipient of the Victoria Cross, the highest military award for gallantry in the face of the enemy given to British and Commonwealth.

Ibrahim Mbouombouo Njoya (d.1933) was the 17th King from a long line of dynasty kings that ruled over Bamun and its people in western Cameroon dating back to the 14th century. 

Under the influence of a German missionary, Njoya converted to Christianity. He later created a new syncretistic religion based on Christianity and traditional Bamum religion before converting to Islam along with much of his court in 1916. He accepted the authority of the Sokoto Caliph, requesting the Caliph send him an Emir's flag and Muslim teachers.
